data.title: Moose Jaw at 49 per cent of average precipitation this winter

data.text:
The overall picture for the province this meteorological winter was warm and dry.

Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC) provided information on the average temperature and precipitation for areas around the province from December through February.

Jesse Wagar, warning preparedness meteorologist with ECCC, pointed to a number of warm spots around the province. “La Ronge, Prince Albert and Yorkton – they all saw their second warmest winters on record.”

La Ronge’s seasonal mean temperature sat at –11.6 degrees Celsius, meaning they were 5.3 degrees warmer than normal. Prince Albert was 5.0 degrees warmer than normal sitting at –10.3 degrees, and Yorkton was 5.4 degrees warmer than normal, with a seasonal mean temperature of –9.1 degrees Celsius.

Moose Jaw saw our 8th warmest winter in 124 years, with a mean temperature from December to February of –7.1 degrees Celsius, or 3.9 degrees warmer than average.

Wagar said that most of the province was 3 to 4 degrees above normal temperatures. “Thats a pretty significant statistic in the climate world.”

The recent deluge of snow that Saskatchewan saw will be included in the spring counts, with ECCC showing a lack of precipitation over the winter. “Areas in the north central region – Key Lake, La Ronge, they saw their driest winters on record,” said Wagar.

Key Lake only saw 46 per cent of normal precipitation with a total of 27.2 mm, and La Ronge was at 28 per cent of normal at 16.0 mm.

We saw our 11th driest winter on record in Moose Jaw. An average amount of precipitation for us is 44.4 mm, and we only saw 21.6 mm – 49 per cent of our average.

While she can’t say for sure what caused the dry and warm winter conditions, there are some possible contributing factors. "This winter was characterized by an El Nino circulation, and that generally does lead to warmer than normal and drier than normal conditions for portions of the Canadian Prairies.”

The meteorological spring period will run from March through May.
